Abstract

Doctoral Dissertation Research: Private-Sector Recruitment Practices in Brazil

This study examines how perceptions affect hiring decisions. The project is grounded in literature on the sociology of labor markets, much of which has been conducted with a focus on hiring practices in the United States. As a case study in point, this project examines hiring processes in corporations located in Brazil, where hiring norms differ significantly from the US and Western Europe. The study also examines whether the gender and race of the applicant affects hiring decisions. The project employs an experimental design that involves vignettes (audit study). Managers associated with selected companies in two cities will be presented with matched resumes of applicants, who represent distinct demographic categories but resemble each other in terms of socioeconomic and human capital dimensions.


Broader Impacts
Brazil is one of the world's largest economies and a major trading partner of the U.S. Employers around the world continue to finetune ways to optimize the recruitment and retention of workers. This also involves adjudicating between qualifications related to human capital and broader company goals, including but not limited to workforce diversity goals. Findings could be of interest to employers, unions, and policy makers. Moreover, findings will be of interest to scholars interested in the social construction of race and its impact on social mobility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From the beginnig of the award, the Co-PI was able to construct the demographic profile of the job applicants for analysis, including social status or class status indicators, gender, and racial backgrounds (black, brown, and white). Human capital variables, such as work experience, education, qualifications and training were also created. Job search engines were identified as potential sources of job ads to be used in the research. A pretest to test for the validity of the race and class status categories was conducted in Brazil through an in-person survey. The proxies used to signal race and class status were refined and confirmed. The profiles of job candidates were created. The data collection process is currently underway. Once the data collection phase is over, the Co-PI will code and organize the data. Once the data is organized, the Co-PI will use logistic regression models to examine the role that race, class, and gender plays in job selection in Brazil. The study will specifically examine the extent to which race and class status interact to inform hiring decisions a Brazilian labor market. These findings should be of interest to policy-makers interested in formulating affirmative action and diversity policies in Brazil. These findings should also be of interest of scholars interested in the construction of race in Brazil. Subsequent analysis of the data will be conducted and the pertinent results will be reported in the form of publications and the Co-PI's dissertation manuscript.
